Projects

Audience Immersion

Hammond et al. (2023), Cognitive Research - Principles and Implications

In this project, we attempt to measure audience immersion in real-time using several continuous physiological and behavioural measures. This project formed the basis of my PhD thesis. Some of these measures we’ve used include - questionnaires, dual-task reaction times, heart rate, skin conductance, recording people’s head and body movements, and most recently EEG.

  • In Hammond et al. (2023), we show that secondary-task reaction times, and intersubject correlation of heart rate, relate to self-reported engagement scores across several short clips (figure below).

  • In Hammond et al. (in prep), we investigate what features of the content are driving audience immersion: low-level audio-visual properties, or the high-level narrative? Evidence suggests that heart rate synchronises between two conditions which only share high-level narrative information, and do not share any low-level features (visual-only with subtitles or audio-only with audio-description). Further, low-level audio-visual saliency only weakly predicts audience heart rate relative to the narrative. Exploratory evidence here suggests that synchrony co-occurs with narratively-important moments - e.g. when a key plot twist is revealed.
